abstracts.cdata!:
Mozambique is rich in minerals and has a
            favorable geological environment for the development of
            mining activities. However, in 2001, the impact of mining on
            the economy was hardly noticeable - representing less than 1
            percent of gross domestic product (GDP) and less than 2
            percent of exports. In addition, the ministry of mineral
            resources estimated that about 10 million dollars in gold
            and 30-40 million dollars in semi-precious stones were
            illegally exported from Mozambique each year. As a result,
            the country seemed to be missing out on a great opportunity
            to expand its economy, create jobs, and reduce poverty. The
            International Development Association (IDA) - financed
            mineral resources management capacity building project was
            launched in 2001 to improve the institutional capacities in
            Mozambique’s mining sector. As a result of this investment,
            mineral exports are set to skyrocket: from approximately
            United States (U.S.) 6 million dollars in average annual
            mineral exports from 2002-2006, to the promise of more than
            U.S. 1 billion dollar annually with the new Moatize coal
            mine, under construction since March 2009. As part of this
            effort, IDA sponsored the resources industries corporate
            social responsibility discussion aimed at enhancing the
            development impact of resource industries through the
            effective use of its revenues and investments in corporate
            social responsibility.
